Sometimes it's the simple innovations that make for the best products. Meet the reinvention of the Bathtub Hair Strainer.

Other
Submitted by: Matthew Zietzke
.

The Description

Loose hair in your tub can collect in your drains and pipes, causing clogs that will prevent your tub from draining properly. In some cases, calling a plumber is the only way to clear the pipes for proper drainage.

While current solutions surely solve this basic problem, they introduce issues of their own. For example, most products currently on the market can't be used for baths because they don't have a proper stopper or place to put your own stopper.

On top of that, over time the strainer will get clogged with the hair that would have become lodged down the drain and only clearing it by hand can clear the flow, but that's messy and gross!

Obviously there has to be a better way to solve this problem.

I propose a solution that allows cleaning the strainer of hair and other debris without touching the mess at all. Using a secondary cover for the strainer that acts both as a stopper and a cleaner for the strainer itself, the Bathtub Hair Strainer can become a more useful tool for the more hairy among us.

This cover will have angled prongs throughout its inner dome that line up with grooves on the strainer portion of the product, allowing it to pick up the debris that collects while draining. A clockwise twist will pick up the hair, while pressing down the center button and twisting counterclockwise will screw the cover in place as a stopper, leaving a smooth surface for feet while still allowing the bath to fill.

Besides, if it's enough of a problem that Boy Meets World addresses it, then it's enough of a problem for Quirky to solve.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_detailpage&v=Rb4ZoRFfgXE#t=800s

The Customer

Homeowners looking to prevent clogged bath and shower drains.

Key Features

  • The strainer captures hair and debris
  • The cap may be twisted clockwise for hands free cleaning of the strainer
  • The cap may be locked in place as a water tight tub stopper

Product Comparison

  • Amazon.com: LDR 501 3400 Plastic Drain Protector: Home Improvement

    •  Reply
    • ▼ 1 Reply
  68. Matthew Zietzke 10 days ago Submitter
    • #
    • #

    This was one of my earliest design problems. In my original submission, I included the center button on the cap as a way of actually pushing the hair off of the prongs, but I just couldn't figure out a way to make it work in my head. I eventually opted for this design because I'm rather confident that only really wet hair will have this issue. If I'm right, then tapping the cap on the side of a trash can should be rather effective at removing the hair, especially because the only places the hair should catch on the top cap are on the prongs themselves rather than becoming otherwise tangled in the unit.

    Of course, no amount of theorizing in my own head can show that it actually works, and I see this as a great opportunity for the Quirky staff to use 3D printed models for testing. That was actually exactly what I wanted to do, but I am unfortunately without a 3D printer and I'm not sure how I could mock this up without it.

    If you (or anyone else) has any thoughts about how to better solve this problem, I'm all ears! I'd love to make this completely fool proof, especially on that front.

    Thank you very much for the valuable thoughts! I know I don't have all the solutions and this isn't (yet) a perfect idea, so any time you can point out a problem is great at readjusting my own perspective on it.

  76. Matthew Zietzke 10 days ago Submitter
    • #
    • #

    Whoops! Hit the wrong reply button. This was in response to Zoran's comment about making it flush to the bottom of the tub.

    This was something I noticed as I was mocking it up in my 3D model. I did think of a solution that shouldn't interfere with the rest of the design, and that is to add holes near the crease between the flat portion and the beginning of the raised section. Just a few small holes would do nicely here.

    The only reason why I didn't include this was because my modeling skills aren't that amazing yet, and I actually made a few mistakes on the topography of the model that make it very difficult to make the change. As it is, the holes within the grooves are somewhat hidden, and that covers up the way that I cheated to make them work. I actually didn't add any depth to the model, so the holes are just places where I deleted faces on the model. If I were to include those holes where they are exposed, I think it would look rather rubbish.

    Thank you very much for the thought, and if you come up with any other flaws in my design, please share them! I like to think I've covered all my bases, but I'm sure there's something I haven't yet considered!

    Ahh, I think I see where the confusion has come from.

    My idea is that the cap unit would screw into the top of the strainer unit. If you look to the main image, there's a hole in the center of the strainer that has threads for the cap to screw into. If you look to the third image that shows the underside of the cap with the hooks, you'll see a piece in the center that would set down into the hole, and it would thread in from there.

  128. Matthew Zietzke 9 days ago Submitter
    • #
    • #

    I don't have the time for the moment to make a diagram on it, but I will try to explain it a little more clearly than the pitch does.

    If you take a look at the third render, the hooks on the underside of the cap unit fit into the grooves on the strainer. In order to clean the unit, my design allows the cap to be twisted clockwise to catch hair that has been caught on the strainer. After twisting, simply pull up on the cap and the hair should come with it.

    For using the unit as a stopper, you press down on the button shown on the top of the cap in the second render, and twist counterclockwise until it is solidly pulled down to stop the flow. There is an integrated screw that you can see a portion of on the underside of the cap (third render again,) that screws into the threads in the hole on the top of the strainer unit.

    Other than that, this works exactly like any other hair strainer. As the 140 char title/pitch says, sometimes it's the simple innovations like these that make the best product.

    I hope this is able to better explain my vision for the product! When I get the time, I'll try to put something together that's a little bit more visual.

    Joe, I believe you're linking to an idea that is no longer visible to the public, something that you submitted before. I remember your idea, and as I recall, unless you made changes that I did not see, your idea did not include design elements for how to achieve the goal.

    In fact, if you're ever able to see my original submission for this idea, I credited you for having an idea that inspired me to go above and beyond your own submission, and I even asked that you'd be given some influence for that very reason. That being said, this idea I have submitted is my own. I came up with the design that actually performs the function, one which your idea merely suggested wouldn't need to be done because it just wouldn't get clogged, and I also added the stopper functionality.

    My point here is that the general idea has been submitted, but not with the functionality that I have included, and there has not been a design until my original submission of this idea which did not include very effective demonstrations of my design. I firmly feel that this idea now stands enough apart from any others' submissions to be taken alone rather than with influence given to others, even if their idea inspired my own.

    I hope I don't sound too aggressive here, since I'm really just giving an explanation, but I do feel the need to be clear about where I stand on the differentiation between my idea and those that others have submitted and why I feel as I do. If you have any questions, please either send me a message, or leave them here for me and message me to let me know so that I don't inadvertently ignore you.
